articles.headline: Stock Buyback Plans, Seen as Shareholder Boon, Can Backfire
articles.snippet: Investors typically like the programs, but they can do serious damage: LPL Financial’s buying spree increased its debt but mostly benefited only an insider.
articles.abstract: Investors typically like the programs, but they can do serious damage: LPL Financial’s buying spree increased its debt but mostly benefited only an insider.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stock buybacks are a boon for shareholders, right?

articles.headline: Shari Redstone Prepares for Battle to Control a Media Empire
articles.snippet: Ms. Redstone says she has patched up her relationship with her media mogul father as a legal battle looms over money and power in the family business.
articles.abstract: Ms. Redstone says she has patched up her relationship with her media mogul father as a legal battle looms over money and power in the family business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shari Redstone pulls her iPhone out of her purse to show off “just one” picture of her grandchildren. She laughs then apologizes when she sees that the back of the phone is covered with heart-shaped stickers — the result of a craft session with the two youngsters.

articles.headline: Test of Zika-Fighting Genetically Engineered Mosquitoes Gets Tentative F.D.A. Approval
articles.snippet: A trial in the Florida Keys has been tentatively approved, but public comment must be assessed first by the agency.
articles.abstract: A trial in the Florida Keys has been tentatively approved, but public comment must be assessed first by the agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government on Friday moved to clear the way for the release of genetically engineered mosquitoes into the wild for the first time in the United States, tentatively approving a field test that might help slow the spread of the Zika virus.

articles.headline: A Smaller Down Payment, and No Mortgage Insurance Required
articles.snippet: Traditionally, home buyers needed a 20 percent down payment to avoid the added cost of mortgage insurance. Now there are ways to get around that.
articles.abstract: Traditionally, home buyers needed a 20 percent down payment to avoid the added cost of mortgage insurance. Now there are ways to get around that.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a year of firsts: In 2015, Kristian and Michele Klein welcomed their first child, a daughter, and bought their first home — a freshly renovated four-bedroom Cape Cod in Glen Head, N.Y.

articles.headline: In South Sudan, City of Hope Is Now City of Fear
articles.snippet: The Republic of South Sudan is not even five years old, but already 50,000 people have been killed in an ethnically driven civil war.
articles.abstract: The Republic of South Sudan is not even five years old, but already 50,000 people have been killed in an ethnically driven civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUBA, South Sudan — Diu Tut glanced up at the gates of the displaced persons camp where he lives and shook his head.

articles.headline: Obama, at South by Southwest, Calls for Law Enforcement Access in Encryption Fight
articles.snippet: President Obama told an audience of technology enthusiasts he supported efforts to gain protected information from electronic devices, opposing the stance taken by Apple.
articles.abstract: President Obama told an audience of technology enthusiasts he supported efforts to gain protected information from electronic devices, opposing the stance taken by Apple.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — President Obama said Friday that law enforcement must be legally able to collect information from smartphones and other electronic devices, making clear, despite disagreement within his administration, that he opposes the stance on encryption taken by technology companies like Apple.

articles.headline: Nancy Reagan’s Abiding Role in her Husband’s Career
articles.snippet: Ronald Reagan credited his wife with saving his soul, and she shrewdly guided him at crucial points in his professional life.
articles.abstract: Ronald Reagan credited his wife with saving his soul, and she shrewdly guided him at crucial points in his professional life.
articles.lead_paragraph: In retrospect, it seems clear that Ronald and Nancy Reagan were not only one of the great married couples of American history, but also one of its great career partnerships. By the time she became first lady, Nancy Reagan had grown immensely from the new wife of March 1952 who was trying to help her 41-year-old bridegroom onto his feet as he reeled from professional setbacks.

articles.headline: As Americans Take Up Populism, the Supreme Court Embraces Business
articles.snippet: The next Supreme Court justice is unlikely to greatly narrow a rift between the country and the court on economic power and support for big business.
articles.abstract: The next Supreme Court justice is unlikely to greatly narrow a rift between the country and the court on economic power and support for big business.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court vacancy created by the death of Justice Antonin Scalia highlights a growing rift between the country and the nation’s highest court on questions of economic power and support for big business.

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Rally in Chicago Canceled After Violent Scuffles
articles.snippet: Protesters and supporters of Donald J. Trump confronted each other, screaming and shoving, at a campaign event Friday that was called off over security concerns.
articles.abstract: Protesters and supporters of Donald J. Trump confronted each other, screaming and shoving, at a campaign event Friday that was called off over security concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — With thousands of people already packed into stands and music blaring to warm up the crowd, Donald J. Trump’s campaign abruptly canceled his rally here on Friday night over security concerns as protesters clashed with his supporters inside an arena where he was to speak.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: States Move to Control How Painkillers Are Prescribed
articles.snippet: A national heroin crisis may be forcing change in how doctors use narcotic painkillers, the most widely prescribed class of drugs in the nation.
articles.abstract: A national heroin crisis may be forcing change in how doctors use narcotic painkillers, the most widely prescribed class of drugs in the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: A growing number of states, alarmed by the rising death toll from prescription painkillers and frustrated by a lack of federal action, are moving to limit how these drugs are prescribed.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: To Maintain Supply of Sex Slaves, ISIS Pushes Birth Control
articles.snippet: Modern methods allow the Islamic State to keep up its systematic rape of captives under medieval codes.
articles.abstract: Modern methods allow the Islamic State to keep up its systematic rape of captives under medieval codes.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHUK, Iraq — Locked inside a room where the only furniture was a bed, the 16-year-old learned to fear the sunset, because nightfall started the countdown to her next rape.

articles.headline: WhatsApp Encryption Said to Stymie Wiretap Order
articles.snippet: A fight with WhatsApp, the world’s largest mobile messaging service, would open a new front in the Obama administration’s dispute with Silicon Valley over encryption, security and privacy.
articles.abstract: A fight with WhatsApp, the world’s largest mobile messaging service, would open a new front in the Obama administration’s dispute with Silicon Valley over encryption, security and privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While the Justice Department wages a public fight with Apple over access to a locked iPhone, government officials are privately debating how to resolve a prolonged standoff with another technology company, WhatsApp, over access to its popular instant messaging application, officials and others involved in the case said.

articles.headline: Remote Utah Enclave Becomes New Battleground Over Reach of U.S. Control
articles.snippet: Conservation groups say a new monument here in the red-rock deserts would protect 1.9 million acres of culturally significant land from new mining and drilling.
articles.abstract: Conservation groups say a new monument here in the red-rock deserts would protect 1.9 million acres of culturally significant land from new mining and drilling.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN COUNTY, Utah — The juniper mesas and sunset-red canyons in this corner of southern Utah are so remote that even the governor says he has probably only seen them from the window of a plane. They are a paradise for hikers and campers, a revered retreat where generations of American Indian tribes have hunted, gathered ceremonial herbs and carved their stories onto the sandstone walls.

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Presidential Run Began in an Effort to Gain Stature
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump’s campaign is driven in part by a deep yearning sometimes obscured by his bluster and bragging: a desire to be taken seriously.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump’s campaign is driven in part by a deep yearning sometimes obscured by his bluster and bragging: a desire to be taken seriously.
articles.lead_paragraph: Get live updates about the Florida primary.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Proud of Obama’s Presidency, Blacks Are Sad to See Him Go
articles.snippet: African-Americans around the country say they are counting down the last 10 months of President Obama’s term with pride, sadness and a looming despair.
articles.abstract: African-Americans around the country say they are counting down the last 10 months of President Obama’s term with pride, sadness and a looming despair.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Get live updates about voting in the March 15 primaries.

articles.headline: Politics Invades Hollywood
articles.snippet: In an election year, the only real “October surprise” from Hollywood would be a complete political blackout. But don’t worry. It won’t happen.
articles.abstract: In an election year, the only real “October surprise” from Hollywood would be a complete political blackout. But don’t worry. It won’t happen.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a presidential election year, the only real “October surprise” from Hollywood would be a complete absence of films with political tinges. But don’t worry. It won’t happen. Already, release schedules for the months preceding Nov. 8, Election Day, are peppered with movies that have partisan potential, whether overt or covert.

articles.headline: Valeant, Woes Rising, Backs Away From Boldness to Calm Investors
articles.snippet: The drug maker, which made big profits by raising the price of old drugs, is now talking about investing in research and paying down debt as its stock price slumps.
articles.abstract: The drug maker, which made big profits by raising the price of old drugs, is now talking about investing in research and paying down debt as its stock price slumps.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back when its stock soared and investors fawned — just six months ago — Valeant Pharmaceuticals billed itself as a new kind of drug company. It thrived on acquiring new drugs rather than inventing them, and generating big profits from raising prices on old, undervalued treatments.

articles.headline: Fed’s Plans to Raise Interest Rates Are Delayed, Not Derailed
articles.snippet: The challenge is to forge consensus among Federal Reserve officials about when to resume the march begun in December, when the central bank raised rates for the first time since the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: The challenge is to forge consensus among Federal Reserve officials about when to resume the march begun in December, when the central bank raised rates for the first time since the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials will gather in Washington on Tuesday and Wednesday to debate whether a bumpy start to the year is now in the rearview mirror, clearing the way for higher interest rates.

articles.headline: Film Academy Governors Take On Race and Ratings
articles.snippet: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science governing board will wrestle with a lack of diversity in its ranks and with poor ratings for the Feb. 28 Oscars telecast.
articles.abstract: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science governing board will wrestle with a lack of diversity in its ranks and with poor ratings for the Feb. 28 Oscars telecast.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The next marquee event at Hollywood’s film academy: “Identity Crisis — Part 2.”
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Baby’s Killing Tests India’s Protection of an Aboriginal Culture
articles.snippet: India has a “hands-off” policy toward hunter-gatherer tribes like the Jarawas. But what happens when a murder inquiry brings the police into an isolated society?
articles.abstract: India has a “hands-off” policy toward hunter-gatherer tribes like the Jarawas. But what happens when a murder inquiry brings the police into an isolated society?
articles.lead_paragraph: OGRABRAJ, India — The police on South Andaman Island know what to do when members of the isolated Jarawa tribe venture into the villages that surround them, hoping to snatch rice and other prized goods, like cookies, bananas or, for some reason, red garments.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry and Hari Kumar

articles.headline: Quiet Support for Saudis Entangles U.S. in Yemen
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has quietly supported the Saudi-led war in Yemen, even as American officials see a bloody quagmire there.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has quietly supported the Saudi-led war in Yemen, even as American officials see a bloody quagmire there.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Adel al-Jubeir, Saudi Arabia’s urbane, well-connected ambassador to Washington, arrived at the White House last March with the urgent hope of getting President Obama’s support for a new war in the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: In the Apple Case, a Debate Over Data Hits Home
articles.snippet: The debate that began three years ago after revelations about government surveillance has become more personal, now that smartphones are involved.
articles.abstract: The debate that began three years ago after revelations about government surveillance has become more personal, now that smartphones are involved.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three years ago, reeling from Edward J. Snowden’s disclosure of the government’s vast surveillance programs and uncertain how to respond, President Obama said he welcomed a vigorous public debate about the wrenching trade-offs between safeguarding personal privacy and tracking down potential terrorists.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Tampa Office Is an Unlikely Melting Pot
articles.snippet: Conversations with volunteers at a small Trump campaign office in an old cigar factory yielded some surprises on the subjects of race, ethnicity and bigotry.
articles.abstract: Conversations with volunteers at a small Trump campaign office in an old cigar factory yielded some surprises on the subjects of race, ethnicity and bigotry.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA — Get live updates about the Florida primary.

articles.headline: Top Start-Up Investors Are Betting on Growth, Not Waiting for It
articles.snippet: Early-stage investors, the venture capitalists who identify and fund a promising company at its infancy, often reap the greatest returns.
articles.abstract: Early-stage investors, the venture capitalists who identify and fund a promising company at its infancy, often reap the greatest returns.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For the last few years, the spotlight in start-up investing has largely shone on those who poured money into a company when it was already well along on a growth path. It turns out that spotlight may have been misdirected.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Ohio Looms Large in Both Races on Tuesday
articles.snippet: A victory by Gov. John Kasich in his home state would toughen Donald J. Trump’s path to the Republican nomination, while Senator Bernie Sanders, a Democrat, seeks a repeat of his Michigan upset.
articles.abstract: A victory by Gov. John Kasich in his home state would toughen Donald J. Trump’s path to the Republican nomination, while Senator Bernie Sanders, a Democrat, seeks a repeat of his Michigan upset.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST CHESTER, Ohio — Get live updates about the Ohio primary and other contests on March 15.

articles.headline: Alaska’s Schools Face Cuts at Every Level Over Oil Collapse
articles.snippet: Educators and state officials said a reckoning over policies and promises made in a different era, under different circumstances, has arrived.
articles.abstract: Educators and state officials said a reckoning over policies and promises made in a different era, under different circumstances, has arrived.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — Alaska’s schools are bleeding red ink.

articles.headline: Labor Protests Multiply in China as Economy Slows, Worrying Leaders
articles.snippet: Concerned about their prospects in a gloomy job market, workers are fighting back with unusual ferocity.
articles.abstract: Concerned about their prospects in a gloomy job market, workers are fighting back with unusual ferocity.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — For nearly seven years, Li Wei rose before dawn seven days a week for his 10-hour shift at the steel plant, returning home each night soaked in sweat, the clank of heavy machinery still ringing in his ears. But last month, the 31-year-old welder stood outside the plant with hundreds of co-workers, picketing against pay cuts and singing patriotic battle hymns.

articles.headline: Marriott-Starwood Deal Is Interrupted by a Chinese Suitor
articles.snippet: Marriott agreed in November to acquire Starwood. Now, the Chinese owner of the Waldorf Astoria is among the competing bidders.
articles.abstract: Marriott agreed in November to acquire Starwood. Now, the Chinese owner of the Waldorf Astoria is among the competing bidders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Around two years ago, the Anbang Insurance Group, an insurer then little known outside of China, announced that it would buy the fabled Waldorf Astoria for $1.95 billion.
articles.byline: By Chad Bray and Leslie Picker

articles.headline: Via Legislative Side Doors, Bernie Sanders Won Modest Victories
articles.snippet: Despite complaints that he is a quixotic crusader, Mr. Sanders has found ways to press his agenda through appending small provisions to larger bills.
articles.abstract: Despite complaints that he is a quixotic crusader, Mr. Sanders has found ways to press his agenda through appending small provisions to larger bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Democrats cobbled together a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s immigration law three years ago, Senator Chuck Schumer of New York was clear about one thing: His party could not suffer a single defection.

articles.headline: Marijuana-Based Drug Found to Reduce Epileptic Seizures
articles.snippet: Epidiolex, in its first major clinical trial, reduced convulsive seizures in young patients with Dravet syndrome, according to GW Pharmaceuticals.
articles.abstract: Epidiolex, in its first major clinical trial, reduced convulsive seizures in young patients with Dravet syndrome, according to GW Pharmaceuticals.
articles.lead_paragraph: An experimental drug derived from marijuana has succeeded in reducing epileptic seizures in its first major clinical trial, the product’s developer announced on Monday, a finding that could lend credence to the medical marijuana movement.
